title: 10. Anatomical and Histological Subdivisions of the Nervous System

vectorData.altText: H5   Anatomical and Histological Subdivisions of the Nervous System

Anatomically, the nervous system is subdivided into two subdivisions:
central nervous system (CNS), consisting of the brain and spinal cord 
peripheral nervous system (PNS), consisting of all neural tissue outside of the brain and spinal cord
Histologically, the nervous system can be subdivided into those tissues that contain neuronal cell bodies (grey matter), and those tissues that are devoid of neuronal cell bodies (white matter).

Glia greatly outnumber neurons. They do not participate directly in information transfer, but play a variety of critically important roles in neural tissue. 
Glia of the CNS are the astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, microglia and ependyma. 
Glia of the PNS are the satellite cells and Schwann Cells.
In the CNS, the relationship of white and grey matter differs between the brain and spinal cord     . In the PNS, grey and white matter is segregated between ganglia and peripheral nerves     .
White & Grey Matter of the CNS
In the CNS, the histological location of white and grey matter in the brain and spinal cord differs.
In the brain, grey matter is located in the cortex     of the cerebral hemispheres, but is also present deep within the brain as basal ganglia.
Cortex is a general term for the most superficial layer of an organ or structure. You will learn that many organs have a cortex – the brain, ovaries, adrenal glands, kidneys…
A coronal section of the brain is illustrated below.
A cross-section of the spinal cord is shown below.
In the spinal cord, grey matter     takes on the shape of the letter ‘H’. It is located within the white matter     .
Grey matter in the CNS is composed of neuronal cell bodies, vessels, glia and axons.
White matter in the spinal cord does not contain neuronal cell bodies, but does contain myelinated/unmyelinated axons. The white that you see is due to the fatty composition of myelin.

Within the Dorsal Root Ganglion (DRG), we find the cell bodies of pseudounipolar neurons (A)    . 
Surrounding the pseudounipolar neurons in the DRG are glial cells referred to as satellite cells(B).
Within the PNS – The Dorsal Root Ganglion & CT Coverings of Nerves
Pseudounipolar neurons are general sensory neurons, their dendrites lie within the periphery and their axon extends to synapse in the CNS.

Peripheral nerves may contain a mixture of:
myelinated and unmyelinated fibres
sensory and motor fibres; i.e. information flows both toward and away from the CNS in a given nerve
somatic and autonomic fibres; i.e. somatic motor fibres controlling skeletal muscle and sympathetic postganglionic fibres controlling smooth muscle or glands may travel together in a given nerve

Epineurium     is the outermost layer of CT covering a peripheral nerve. Within epineurium, fascicles can be seen, each covered by perineurium    . Removing the perineurium, individual axons are surrounded by endoneurium          .
Larger nerves may consist of multiple fascicles bound together by epineurium, areolar CT that includes larger vessels and forms a condensed sheath surrounding the nerve.
Axons are bundled together as fascicles, surrounded by perineurium, a more dense irregular CT.
Areolar CT covering an axon and its Schwann cells, inc. dense, fine capillaries as well.

A low magnification light micrograph shows a small peripheral nerve composed of eight fascicles. Each fascicle is surrounded by perineurium. Vessels are embedded in the loose CT of the epineurium.

 F = fascicle                        V = vessel P = perineurium	       E = epineurium

A transmission electron micrograph of a peripheral nerve fascicle shows a mixture of myelinated and unmyelinated fibres. The fibres and their Schwann cells are surrounded by endoneurium, produced by fibroblasts

M = myelinated axon              N = non-myelinated axonS = Schwann cell nucleus        Mi = mitochondriaF = fibroblast
Within the PNS – The Dorsal Root Ganglion & CT Coverings of Nerves
